criteria: Understanding the concept of solving equations and inequalities
Ability to use substitution to verify solutions.
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate understanding of what it means to solve an equation or inequality.
Student shows limited understanding, struggling to articulate the purpose of solving equations and inequalities.
Student demonstrates some understanding but has difficulty explaining how specific values make the equation or inequality true.
Student demonstrates a clear understanding of solving equations/inequalities, recognizing it as finding values that satisfy the condition.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding, clearly explaining the solution process and its meaning.
Student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding, articulating the purpose of solving equations and inequalities with depth and precision.
Student cannot use substitution to check if a given value satisfies an equation or inequality.
Student attempts to use substitution but makes significant errors in the process.
Student can substitute values but struggles with arithmetic or algebraic manipulation, leading to incorrect conclusions.
Student accurately substitutes values and performs calculations to determine if a given value is a solution.
Student consistently and accurately uses substitution to verify solutions and can explain the results.
Student expertly uses substitution and clearly explains how substitution can prove or disprove an equation
Student is unable to identify any values that satisfy the equation or inequality.
Student can identify possible solutions, but they are incomplete or inaccurate.
Student identifies some correct solutions but misses others or includes incorrect values.
Student correctly identifies the set of values that make the equation or inequality true.
Student accurately identifies and justifies the complete solution set.
Student flawlessly determines the complete solution sets even given complex equations and inequalities.
